item.title: Bank of Korea Flags More Rate Cuts to Come as Tariffs Hit Growth
item.description: The Bank of Korea flagged the likelihood of more interest rate cuts to come after trimming borrowing costs on Thursday and slashing this year’s growth forecast as Donald Trump’s tariffs and political turmoil weigh on the economy.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: The Global Tussle For The Port of Darwin
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: Host Rebecca Jones speaks to government reporter Ben Westcott and senior editor Chelsea Mes about the strategic significance of the Port of Darwin.

media:content.media:description: The access entry to the Port of Darwin. Photographer: Darrian Traynor/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Trump’s Global Tariffs Deemed Illegal, Blocked by Trade Court
item.description: The vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs were deemed illegal and blocked by the US trade court, dealing a major blow to a pillar of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump

item.title: US Ally South Korea Set to Improve China Ties If Lee Wins Vote
item.description: A win for the left-of-center frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential election would likely herald more caution by Seoul over taking sides in US-China rivalry, a new effort to draw North Korea into dialogue and the potential for tension with Japan.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung speaks at a campaign event in Uijeongbu on May 20.

item.title: RBNZ Governor Hawkesby Says July Rate Cut ‘Is Not a Done Deal’
item.description: New Zealand’s central bank could hold the Official Cash Rate steady at its next policy decision in July, Governor Christian Hawkesby said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Brockett

media:content.media:description: Christian Hawkesby Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

item.title: Economists Cut Thai, Malaysian Growth Forecasts on Trade Turmoil
item.description: Economists have slashed forecasts for growth in Malaysia and Thailand as the export-dependent economies grapple with US President Donald Trump’s global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Tomoko Sato

media:content.media:description: Malaysia’s central bank said earlier this month that it has policy room to act, as it expects growth to fall below the official forecast this year.

item.title: Banxico Sees Growth of 0.1% This Year, Rules Out Recession
item.description: Mexico’s central bank cut its growth forecasts for this year and next amid mounting signs that Latin America’s second-biggest economy is stalling. However, the bank doesn’t expect a recession.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Mexico's central bank headquarters, the Banco de Mexico, in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. The Mexican peso slumped after US President Donald Trump imposed new import tariffs against the country, though other developing-nation currencies held their own amid concerns about the impact of the escalating trade war on growth in the world's largest economy.

item.title: Why Tariffs Won’t Fix America’s Problems
item.description: On Trumponomics, author Richard Baldwin warns that Donald Trump’s trade war won’t accomplish its stated goals—and that the world may simply move on.
item.dc:creator: Tala Ahmadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, right, and Xi Jinping, China's president, following their meeting Paris, France, on Monday, May 6, 2024. The French government will sign a wide-ranging pact with the automotive industry on Monday that sets new targets for electric vehicle sales, just as Xi arrives for a state visit clouded by trade tensions in the sector.

item.title: Fed Well Positioned to Wait for Clarity on Outlook, Minutes Say
item.description: Federal Reserve officials broadly agreed heightened economic uncertainty justified their patient approach to interest-rate adjustments, minutes from their latest policy meeting showed Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: The Federal Reserve building in Washington. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Merz Vows Legislative Action to Quickly Boost German Economy
item.description: Germany’s new ruling coalition agreed to push ahead with measures aimed at stimulating the struggling economy and to enact as much legislation as possible before leaving for summer break in mid-July.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor, during a news conference with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Chancellery in Berlin, Germany, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. Zelenskiy called on western allies to provide about $30 billion by the end of the year to boost domestic weapons production and hold off Russia’s advance.

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Says More Rate Cuts Possible in Coming Weeks
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said more reductions in borrowing costs could be on the way, with little sign at present of upward pressure on consumer prices.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: AfDB Sees Cedi Among African Currencies Slipping in 2025
item.description: Almost half of the currencies in Africa will weaken against the dollar this year, according to the African Development Bank, citing geopolitical strains and domestic economic challenges.
item.dc:creator: Emele Onu

media:content.media:description: A customer hands a vendor a naira banknote to a vendor in Lagos, Nigeria.

item.title: About 73% of Americans Doing At Least OK in Fed Survey
item.description: Americans were mostly financially stable and had a slightly less pessimistic view of the economy at the end of last year, according to an annual survey by the Federal Reserve.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: A shopper holds a $20 bill while waiting to pay at a store in Walnut Creek, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Knot Says Inflation May Cause Considerable Challenges
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Klaas Knot warned that “historically large shocks” in the global economy and their fallout on prices will be hard to navigate and require flexibility from policymakers.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

item.title: Mexico’s Judicial Reform Is Now in the Hands of Confused Voters
item.description: Lea la nota en español
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Advertisement promoting the judicial elections in Iztapalapa, Mexico City, Monday, May 12, 2025. Fred Ramos for Bloomberg

item.title: Malaysian Ministers Quit in Blow to Anwar’s Government
item.description: Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli and Natural Resources and Environmental Sustainability Minister Nik Nazmi Nik Ahmad are leaving the cabinet, days after they were defeated in an internal party election that was marred by allegations of vote-rigging and nepotism.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Rafizi Ramli Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: US Home-Refinancing Gauge Falls to Three-Month Low as Rates Near 7%
item.description: US home-refinance applications slipped last week to a three-month low as mortgage rates neared 7%.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

media:content.media:description: Homes in Hercules, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei Intervenes in Currency Market Despite Letting Argentine Peso Float
item.description: After pledging a free-floating currency a month ago, Argentina’s government has intervened in the market to influence the peso’s value, a move that stands in sharp contrast to its commitments to the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Argentina in Buenos Aires. Photographer: Erica Canepa/Bloomberg

item.title: Central Bankers Bow to Political Winds When It Comes to Climate, Study Shows
item.description: Central bank independence is about more than just interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Marsh

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), from left, Kazuo Ueda, governor of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), and Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, at the Jackson Hole economic symposium in Moran, Wyoming, US, on Friday, Aug. 25, 2023. Powell said the US central bank is prepared to raise interest rates further if needed and intends to keep borrowing costs high until inflation is on a convincing path toward the Fed's 2% target.

item.title: Why Euro Crisis Looms Large for the White House Chief Economist
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at some thoughts on US financial vulnerability sketched by the White House chief economist. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: European Firms Lose Confidence in China Operations, Survey Shows
item.description: European companies operating in China are the most pessimistic about growth prospects since 2011, a new survey shows.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Lagarde Discussed Leaving ECB Early for WEF, Schwab Tells FT
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde has discussed cutting short her term to chair the World Economic Forum, the organization’s departed founder Klaus Schwab told the Financial Times in an interview.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde at the World Economic Forum in Davos, on Jan. 24. Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ’s Bond Holding Paper Losses Hit Record After Rate Hikes
item.description: The Bank of Japan amassed the largest amount of unrealized losses on record from its government bond holdings in the year ended March, highlighting the challenges it faces in unwinding more than a decade of extraordinary monetary easing.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: Trump’s Nippon Steel Bid Support Boosts Japan’s Trade Talk Hopes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s pivot to champion Nippon Steel Corp.’s bid to buy US Steel Corp. raises the prospect of fresh positive momentum for Japan’s sluggish negotiations with the US over tariff relief.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: The US Steel Corp. Edgar Thomson Works in Braddock, Pennsylvania, US. Photographer: Justin Merriman/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea’s Lee Sees Lead Grow in Opinion Poll as Vote Looms
item.description: South Korea’s presidential frontrunner Lee Jae-myung increased his lead over ruling party nominee Kim Moon-soo, according to the latest opinion poll, another sign that he is well placed to triumph in next week’s election if the conservative vote remains split.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung arrives for a campaign event in Incheon, South Korea, on May 21. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: China Deflation Worry Is Eclipsing Trade War Thaw for Economists
item.description: Economists expect deflationary pressure to get worse in China, even as they improve forecasts for growth and exports this year after a truce in the trade war with the US.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li, Yujing Liu

item.title: ECB Says Consumers’ Inflation Expectations Rise for Second Month
item.description: Inflation expectations of euro-area consumers increased for a second month in April, the European Central Bank said.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Bremen. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Zambia Joins Ghana in Asserting Afreximbank Debt-Rework Plan
item.description: Zambia will restructure its debt with regional lenders including the African Export-Import Bank and remain in default on those payments until it completes the process, Finance Minister Situmbeko Musokotwane said.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Matthew Hill

media:content.media:description: Situmbeko Musokotwane

item.title: French Consumer Spending Rises Less Than Expected in April
item.description: French consumer spending rose less than expected in April in a tepid pick-up after weak household demand weighed on economic growth at the start of the year.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: The Les Halles shopping mall in Paris. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Seeks Approval to Raise $24 Billion in Foreign Loans
item.description: Nigeria’s President Bola Tinubu has requested approval from lawmakers to raise almost $24 billion in external borrowing in the next two years to fund projects that will spur economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Bola Tinubu
